questions.question: Which reagent is used to selectively precipitate nickel in gravimetric estimation?

explanations.a: Oxalic acid is not selective for nickel precipitation.
explanations.b: Dimethyl glyoxime forms a red precipitate specifically with nickel ions, making it selective.
explanations.c: EDTA is a chelating agent, not used for precipitation in this method.
explanations.d: Ammonium oxalate is not commonly used for nickel gravimetric analysis.

questions.question: What is the role of ammonia in the gravimetric estimation of nickel?

answers.c: To maintain the pH for chelation

explanations.a: Ammonia does not primarily function to dissolve the complex.
explanations.b: Temperature adjustment is not the role of ammonia here.
explanations.c: Ammonia maintains an alkaline pH, facilitating nickel chelation with dimethyl glyoxime.
explanations.d: Ammonia does not act as an oxidizing agent in this context.

questions.question: Why is it important to avoid adding a large excess of dimethyl glyoxime in this experiment?

answers.a: It forms complexes with water molecules
answers.b: It may lead to precipitation of DMG itself
answers.c: It causes the nickel complex to evaporate
answers.d: It reduces the solubility of the nickel complex

explanations.a: DMG does not typically form stable complexes with water molecules.
explanations.b: Excess DMG can precipitate independently, interfering with accurate nickel estimation.
explanations.c: Nickel-DMG complex is not volatile; it does not evaporate.
explanations.d: Solubility of the complex is not significantly reduced by excess DMG.
